title: Haematopoiesis
summary: Haematopoiesis (/hɪˌmætoʊpɔɪˈiːsɪs, ˈhiːmətoʊ-, ˌhɛmə-/,[1] from Greek αἷμα, 'blood' and ποιεῖν 'to make'; also hematopoiesis in American English; sometimes also h(a)emopoiesis) is the formation of blood cellular components. All cellular blood components are derived from haematopoietic stem cells.[2] In a healthy adult person, approximately 1011–1012 new blood cells are produced daily in order to maintain steady state levels in the peripheral circulation.[3][4]
